answers.answer: What are your actual thyroid levels?  Just because they are in the normal range, doesn't mean they are normal for you.  If they are too low in the range, you will have symptoms, such as the ones you have.You should be getting tested for TSH, Free T3 and Free T4.  Many doctors will only test TSH, thinking that it tells everything there is to know about thyroid function, when that couldn't be further from the truth.  If your doctor refuses to test Free T3 and Free T4, which are actual thyroid hormones, you should find a different doctor.What tests did you actually have done?  Have you been tested for Hashimoto's?I don't know that it's necessary to have your kids tested, at this point, if they have no symptoms, but I'd certainly keep an eye out for any type of possible autoimmune disease, since some in your family have RA, which is autoimmune.  Do your mother and aunt have Hashimoto's?  Hashimoto's is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the developed world.  Hashimoto's is another autoimmune.Autoimmune diseases tend to run families, but not every member gets the same disease.  For instance, in my family, I have Hashimoto's and Pernicious Anemia, my son has Type I diabetes and my daughter has Lupus.  Those are all autoimmune.  Additionally, when a person has one autoimmune, chances of them getting another is greater.You should also look into insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.  I have both.

My level was right at the bottom of the normal range, right on the cusp but as it was still in the normal range they didn't proceed with any further investigation. I have recently moved house so need to register with a new doctor so I will definitely bring it up with them and have them test for all 3 three even if I have to pay for it. I have been tested for Diabetes a number of times and I am always fine - I am not worried about that side of things.Kind regards,Celeste
